original_data.question: A 30-year-old male presents to his primary care physician complaining of infertility. He and his wife have been trying to get pregnant for the past two years. They have used fertility monitors and other aids without success. A hysterosalpingogram in his wife was normal. The patient has a history of cleft lip and recurrent upper respiratory infections as a child. He was briefly hospitalized for severe pneumonia when he was 9-years-old. His temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 120/85 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 18/min. On examination, he is a healthy-appearing male in no acute distress with fully developed reproductive organs. Notably, cardiac auscultation is silent in the left 5th intercostal space at the midclavicular line. This patient most likely has a mutation in which of the following classes of proteins?

model_response:
The patient has a bicuspid aortic valve, which is a congenital heart defect. The most common genetic defect associated with bicuspid aortic valve is a mutation in the NOTCH1 gene, which encodes a transmembrane ion channel protein. The NOTCH1 gene is also associated with a higher risk of atherosclerosis. Microtubule monomeric proteins (choice A) are associated with cystic medial degeneration of the aorta, which is not a feature of bicuspid aortic valve. Mutations in the RET proto-oncogene (choice C) are associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2). Mutations in the kinesin motor protein (choice D) are associated with Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease. Mutations in the dynein motor protein (choice E) are associated with primary ciliary dyskinesia.

###Answer: OPTION B IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: A person who belongs to the sex that normally produces sperm. The term is used to indicate biological sex distinctions, cultural gender role distinctions, or both.
Providers of initial care for patients. These PHYSICIANS refer patients when appropriate for secondary or specialist care.
A symptom or problem for which a patient seeks medical attention.
A reduced or absent capacity to reproduce.
A female partner in marriage.
Observed to be or have been pregnant.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
The capacity to conceive or to induce conception. It may refer to either the male or female.
A device than includes a sensor designed to give information about the presence of a substance or the state of a system.

An acquired defect of cellular immunity associated with infection by the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), a CD4-positive T-lymphocyte count under 200 cells/microliter or less than 14% of total lymphocytes, and increased susceptibility to opportunistic infections and malignant neoplasms. Clinical manifestations also include emaciation (wasting) and dementia. These elements reflect criteria for AIDS as defined by the CDC in 1993.
An event that accomplishes its intended purpose.
Radiography of the uterus and fallopian tubes after the injection of a contrast medium.
A female partner in marriage.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Record and study of past events.

Congenital defect in the upper lip where the maxillary prominence fails to merge with the merged medial nasal prominences. It is thought to be caused by faulty migration of the mesoderm in the head region.

Applied to a sign, symptom, or other manifestation that occurs multiple times at usually irregular intervals. The occurences are separated by an interval in which the sign, symptom, or manifestation is not present. []
An infectious process affecting the upper respiratory tract (nose, paranasal sinuses, pharynx, larynx, or trachea). Symptoms include congestion, sneezing, coughing, fever, and sore throat.
A person 6 to 12 years of age. An individual 2 to 5 years old is CHILD, PRESCHOOL.
Intensely bad or unpleasant in degree, quality or extent.
Infection of the lung often accompanied by inflammation.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A non-SI unit of pressure equal to 133,332 Pa or 1.316E10-3 standard atmosphere. Use of this unit is generally deprecated by ISO and IUPAC.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.

The act of breathing with the LUNGS, consisting of INHALATION, or the taking into the lungs of the ambient air, and of EXHALATION, or the expelling of the modified air which contains more CARBON DIOXIDE than the air taken in (Blakiston's Gould Medical Dictionary, 4th ed.). This does not include tissue respiration (= OXYGEN CONSUMPTION) or cell respiration (= CELL RESPIRATION).
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
A person who belongs to the sex that normally produces sperm. The term is used to indicate biological sex distinctions, cultural gender role distinctions, or both.
A state of physiological or psychological stress that cannot be compensated for by normal adaptive measures.
The external and internal organs involved in the functions of REPRODUCTION.
Act of listening for sounds within the heart.
Being or located on or directed toward the side of the body to the west when facing north.
Space of compartment of trunk bounded by the upper and lower surfaces of two consecutive ribs.

sense organ found in aquatic vertebrates consisting of cutaneous mechanoreceptors called neuromasts; in advanced species the neuromasts are located in a longitudinal canal; used for detecting prey, obstacle avoidance, and in schooling behavior.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Any detectable and heritable change in the genetic material that causes a change in the GENOTYPE and which is transmitted to daughter cells and to succeeding generations.
A grouping of things based on shared common attributes.

Linear POLYPEPTIDES that are synthesized on RIBOSOMES and may be further modified, crosslinked, cleaved, or assembled into complex proteins with several subunits. The specific sequence of AMINO ACIDS determines the shape the polypeptide will take, during PROTEIN FOLDING, and the function of the protein.
